As I think for possible implementations for fingerprint 
recognition/classi=
fication with existing HyperNEAT software, I can 
raise the following issue=
s:

- My current experiments with ActiveVision show that it is hard to 
evo=
lve substrates that recognize simple shapes that are randomly 
rotated. Per=
haps I should tweak the NEAT parameters or the set of 
activation functions=
? 

- I suggest using a 3D substrate space, where the inputs are located 
o=
n a plane, in a grid configuration, and the hidden and outputs are 
on sepa=
rate planes behind it. This way is possible to avoid the 
problem of decidi=
ng where to put the hidden and output neurons in a 
2D substrate space.

- =
The input resoluton has to be extremely high in order to handle 
fingerprin=
ts correctly. Something like 100x100 grayscale or above. 
Starting at a low=
er resolution and increasing node density will not 
help much, since at the=
 lower resolution the fingerprint gets dizzy 
and even a human cannot say w=
hat is it :)

- Such a high resolution means that there should be some very=
 good 
optimization method, in order to construct the substrates as quickly=
 
as possible. 

- The fitness function should be more complex than just "t=
his is the 
image/this is not the image".. But I can't think of it.. Do you=
 have 
any suggestions? Perhaps something like "I am 10% sure that this is =

the image"? 

Peter

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Kenneth Stanley" <kstan=
ley@...> wrote:
>
> Actually, this made me realize, HyperNEAT could potenti=
ally be good 
> for fingerprint recognition/classification since it can dea=
l with 
> high resolution inputs and can also do a good job perceiving 
> r=
egularities, which means that it can potentially learn to identify 
> an im=
portant feature even if that feature is not always in the same 
> place.
> =

> ken
>

hould check out "ActiveVision.zip" in the

 ANJI. It is actually just the

I
